author: hvdkooij
body:
Access rights out of the tgz file are not correct for the arm32 build for Raspberry PI.

```
$ pwd
/opt/microsoft/powershell/6.1.2
$ ls -lasi pwsh
262562 76 -rwxrw-rw- 1 root root 77172 Jan 10 01:24 pwsh
```

Not sure why these files are NOT executable but are WRITABLE for all.

Based on todays installation of powershell-6.1.2-linux-arm32.tar.gz

At this moment only root can use powershell but everyone can insert whatever trouble into 

```
$ ls -l
total 102880
drwxr-xr-x  2 root root    4096 Jan 10 01:24 cs
```

comments.author: hvdkooij
comments.body:
Work around:

```
sudo chmod 755 *.dll
sudo chmod 755 *.a
sudo chmod 755 *.so
sudo chmod 755 pwsh
```

comments.author: hvdkooij
comments.body:
Just confirmed the issue is still a problem in 6.1.3
This seems a silly distribution issue that can get fixes in a minute?

comments.author: qmfrederik
comments.body:
This is also the case for the arm64 builds.

Scenario:
- I have an Ubuntu Docker image which I use as a build container with Azure DevOps
- I install PowerShell Core in this image using the .tar.gz archive (the only distribution method offered for arm64)
- This results in `pwsh` with the `-rwxrw-rw-` flags
- Azure DevOps will generate a new user in the container (i.e. not root), and invoking `pwsh` fails: `/usr/local/bin/pwsh: Permission denied`

comments.author: qmfrederik
comments.body: As a sidenote, it suffices to just do `chmod +x pwsh`, `.dll`, `.a` and `.so` do not need to be executable (but it doesn't harm, either).

comments.author: msftbot[bot]
comments.body: This issue has been marked as fixed and has not had any activity for **1 day**. It has been closed for housekeeping purposes.

title: [BUG] ARM (Raspbian) build has incorrect rights.
